CARDINAL . The references made in the following pertain to chapter QUANTITY of LAW ( Rättegångsbalken ; hereinafter “ the Code ” ) , if not otherwise indicated .

CARDINAL . The suspect may conduct the defence on his or her own ( section CARDINAL ) or with the assistance of a defence counsel ( section CARDINAL ) who , as a main rule , is appointed by the suspect ( section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ) . A defence counsel so appointed is referred to as private defence counsel , as opposed to CARDINAL appointed by a court who is referred to as public defence counsel .

CARDINAL . Public defence counsel is to be appointed for a person who is arrested or in detention , if he or she so requests . Upon request , such counsel will also be appointed for a person suspected of an offence for which the statutory penalty is imprisonment for DATE ( section CARDINAL a , subsection CARDINAL ) . In addition , public defence counsel must be appointed under either of the following circumstances : ( CARDINAL ) if the suspect is in need of counsel due to the criminal investigation , ( CARDINAL ) if there is such a need on account of it being uncertain which penalty will be imposed and there is reason to impose a penalty other than a fine or a conditional sentence or a combination of those penalties , or ( CARDINAL ) there are other special reasons relating to the suspect ’s personal situation or the subject matter of the case ( section CARDINAL a , subsection CARDINAL ) . However , if the suspect has already appointed defence counsel , no additional public counsel is to be appointed ( section CARDINAL a , subsection CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The court considers the question of appointing public defence counsel if such appointment has been requested or it finds cause therefor of its own motion ( section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ) . A request for the appointment of public defence counsel may be made by the suspect or the public prosecutor responsible for the pre - trial investigation . In deciding this issue , the starting - point for the court is whether there is a need for counsel considering the character of the matter at stake . According to the preparatory documents to the legislation ( Government PERSON , p. CARDINAL ) , there may not be any consideration of the suspect ’s economic situation in this context .

CARDINAL . The suspect has a certain influence on the appointment of public defence counsel . Thus , the person suggested by the suspect is to be appointed if he or she is competent and the appointment would not cause a considerable increase in the costs or there are other special reasons against that appointment ( section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ) . According to the preparatory documents ( Nytt juridiskt arkiv ( NJA ) II DATE , p. CARDINAL ) , it is important that the suspect has confidence in the person assisting him or her . Somebody else than the person suggested should be appointed only if the above - mentioned reasons are at hand . There is no right to have public defence counsel who speaks the suspect ’s mother tongue , but such considerations may be taken into account . Otherwise , the matter of language is solved by using interpreters paid out of public funds .

CARDINAL . The appointment of public defence counsel may be revoked if there is no longer a need for such counsel or if there is some other justifiable reason . If the suspect authorises another person than the publicly appointed counsel to conduct his or her defence , the appointment is to be revoked , unless this would cause considerable inconvenience ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . A publicly appointed counsel may also be replaced ; such a replacement , however , has to be supported by justifiable reasons ( see NJA II DATE , p. CARDINAL ) . There are some examples in case - law of how this issue has been dealt with by the courts .

CARDINAL . In CARDINAL case ( NJA DATE , p. CARDINAL ) ORG allowed that public defence counsel be replaced on the ground that special importance had to be attached to a lack in the defendant ’s confidence in his counsel when there was a risk of long - term imprisonment and there could be differing opinions as to what evidence should be presented to the court . ORG had sentenced the defendant to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for , inter alia , an aggravated narcotics offence .

CARDINAL . Another case ( NJA DATE , p. CARDINAL ) concerned an accused who , pleading not guilty , had been sentenced for murder to life imprisonment . ORG stated that in such a case , where the accused had no confidence in his public defence counsel , he should be allowed to have that counsel replaced .

CARDINAL . In a third case ( PERSON hovrätterna ( ORG ) CARDINAL ) a NORP national was suspected of murder . ORG did not allow the replacement of his public defence counsel in favour of someone who was able to speak NORP .

CARDINAL . Private defence counsel is paid for by the suspect . If the suspect is acquitted , the costs of the defence are normally reimbursed . Public defence counsel , however , is paid out of public funds ( Section CARDINAL a ) . LAW of the LAW regulates who will eventually bear counsel ’s costs in such a case . Normally , if the suspect is convicted , he or she will have to pay the costs of the defence , in whole or in part , depending on his or her economic situation . If the suspect is acquitted , the ORG will bear the costs , as with the costs of private defence counsel .

CARDINAL . A decision by a ORG to refuse a request for the appointment of public defence counsel , or a decision to appoint another counsel than the CARDINAL suggested by the suspect , may be appealed against to a ORG and further to ORG .
